This appeal concerns the payment of withholding tax in terms of the

to set out the history of the matter in greater detail than would otherwise have been
necessary.
[1] The Act in chapter 4 contained provisions relating to withholding tax. At
this stage it is only necessary to note that a withholding tax was to be paid in respect
ot i a, dividends declared or paid by a Ciskeian company at the rate of 15 cents in the
Rand
(s 12). According to s 13(a)(iii) as originally enacted "the withholding tax [had
to] be paid in respect of the amount of... any dividend declared or paid by a Ciskeian
company ... if the person to whom such amount has been paid or is payable is ... an
external company." An "external company" was defined in s 1 to mean "any company
other than a Ciskeian company" and a Ciskeian company, in turn, was defined to

Ciskei
.
[2] The first appellant, Cohen Brothers Furniture (Pty) Ltd (hereinafter "Cohen
Bros"), was a company incorporated in
South Africa
, and thus an external company
according to the definition. The second appellant, Allied Re-Insurance Co (Pty) Ltd
("Allied"), on the other hand, was a Ciskeian company as defined. Allied was a
wholly owned subsidiary of Cohen Bros.
[3] On 4 February 1991 and again on 3 September 1991 Allied declared
dividends of, respectively, R21 006 799 and R16 500 000. Allied deducted
withholding tax amounting to R3 151 019,85 and R2 475 000 in respect of these
dividends from the amount due to Cohen Bros and paid the tax over to the Receiver of
Revenue on 4 March 1991 and 27 September 1991. This was done pursuant to the
provisions of s 16(a) of the Act to which I shall revert. The balance of the dividends
was paid to Cohen Bros shortly after having been declared.

54 SATC 456

sitting as President of the

(

between the

.
[5] The double taxation agreement between
South Africa
and

was in
terms similar or identical to the agreement referred to in [4]. Alluding to that fact and
Melamet J's judgment, Cohen Bros requested the Receiver to refund the withholding
tax paid by Allied. The Commissioner took legal advice and in consequence, one can

be paid in respect of the amount of ... any dividend declared or paid by a Ciskeian
company ... if the person to whom such amount has been paid or is payable is ... a
company which has its place of effective management outside
Ciskei
."
Furthermore, s 3 of the Decree stated that it "shall be deemed to have come into

[6] It is common cause that the place of effective management of Cohen Bros was outside

sections.facts: The case arose from the payment of a withholding tax on dividends declared by Allied Re‑Insurance Co (a Ciskeian company) and paid to its parent, Cohen Brothers Furniture (an external South African company). Under the original Income Tax Act, a 15‑cent per Rand tax was payable on dividends to any external company. Allied deducted and remitted the tax in 1991. The appellants sought a refund, arguing that the tax conflicted with a double‑taxation agreement. The Ciskei Government subsequently amended the Act by Decree No 2 of 1993, deleting the definition of “external company” and substituting a test based on the recipient’s place of effective management outside Ciskei, with retrospective effect to 1 March 1985.
sections.issues: 1. Whether the 1993 amendment, with its retrospective effect, was constitutionally valid and did not infringe fundamental rights. 2. Whether the amendment violated the double‑taxation agreement between South Africa and Ciskei by discriminating on the basis of nationality. 3. Whether the appellants were entitled to a refund of the withholding tax already paid.
sections.principles: The court considered the doctrine of non‑retroactivity of legislation, the constitutional requirement that laws must not discriminate arbitrarily, and the primacy of double‑taxation agreements under international law. It also examined the legal definition of “place of effective management” as the appropriate test for residency and the limits on legislative power to amend tax liabilities retrospectively.
sections.application: Applying these principles, the court evaluated whether the Decree’s deletion of the “external company” definition and its retrospective operation altered the tax position of past periods in a manner inconsistent with constitutional protections or the treaty. The court found that the amendment was a lawful exercise of legislative authority, that it did not constitute prohibited discrimination because it applied a neutral residency test, and that the retrospective date was permissible because the amendment clarified existing statutory intent rather than imposing a new burden.
sections.conclusion: The Supreme Court of Appeal upheld the validity of the Income Tax Amendment Decree, rejected the appellants’ claim for a refund, and confirmed that the withholding tax deducted by Allied was lawfully payable. The amendment was held to be constitutional, non‑discriminatory, and consistent with the double‑taxation agreement.
